Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: 7. In light of the above, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court modify the existing custody Order to ensure the safety and well-being of the minor children.

Adams v. Adams, 459 Mass. 361, 388 (2011.proposition: 7. In light of the above, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court modify the existing custody Order to ensure the safety and well-being of the minor children.
Adams v. Adams, 459 Mass. 361, 388 (2011.support_reasoning: The excerpted portion of Adams v. Adams concerns impoundment of court records and the appellate court’s authority to modify an impoundment order on its own initiative. It does not address custody standards, modification of custody orders, or judicial authority to change custody to protect the safety and well-being of children. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for a request to modify an existing custody order for child safety reasons.
Adams v. Adams, 459 Mass. 361, 388 (2011.relevant_excerpt: Given the court’s ruling, it may make sense for our rules committee to reexamine the rule on impounded appeals, S.J.C. Rule 1:15. I am concerned that the rule as it is currently written may give parties and nonparties who have obtained impoundment orders in the trial court a false sense of assurance that the impoundment will be honored by the appellate court if it is not being challenged. Perhaps the rule should be changed to require one who has obtained an impoundment order in the trial court to apply anew to the appellate court for impoundment of the appeal.

Hernandez v. Hernandez, 445 Mass. 230, 2.proposition: 7. In light of the above, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court modify the existing custody Order to ensure the safety and well-being of the minor children.
Hernandez v. Hernandez, 445 Mass. 230, 2.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case concerning child rape, sufficiency of evidence, admissibility of prior convictions, and the fresh (first) complaint doctrine. It does not involve custody, domestic relations, or standards for modification of a custody order to protect children’s safety. Accordingly, it provides no authority for a request to modify an existing custody order to ensure the safety and well-being of minor children.

Jones v. Jones, 430 Mass. 711, 731 (2000.proposition: 7. In light of the above, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court modify the existing custody Order to ensure the safety and well-being of the minor children.
Jones v. Jones, 430 Mass. 711, 731 (2000.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal homicide appeal dealing with probable cause for a search warrant and the effect of psychiatric testimony under G.L. c. 278, § 33E. It does not involve family law, custody, or modification of custody orders, nor does it articulate any standard about modifying custody to protect the safety and well-being of children. Therefore it provides no authority for the requested modification of a custody order.
Jones v. Jones, 430 Mass. 711, 731 (2000.relevant_excerpt:
We decline to exercise our power under G. L. c. 278, § 33E, to grant a new trial or reduce the verdict.
...
We see no reason to exercise our power under G. L. c. 278, § 33E, to reduce the verdict to a lesser degree of guilt or to order a new trial.

Judgment affirmed.

Jacobs v. Jacobs, 419 Mass. 107, 128 (19.proposition: 7. In light of the above, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court modify the existing custody Order to ensure the safety and well-being of the minor children.
Jacobs v. Jacobs, 419 Mass. 107, 128 (19.support_reasoning: The case is a criminal double-jeopardy/sufficiency-of-the-evidence decision concerning a mother's prosecution for murder of her child. It does not involve family law, custody standards, or modification of custody orders to protect minor children. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the requested proposition about modifying a custody order for the safety and well-being of children.

Smith v. Smith, 395 Mass. 109, 130 (1985.proposition: 7. In light of the above, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court modify the existing custody Order to ensure the safety and well-being of the minor children.
Smith v. Smith, 395 Mass. 109, 130 (1985.case_name: Cruz v. Commissioner of Public Welfare
Smith v. Smith, 395 Mass. 109, 130 (1985.support_reasoning: The case concerns Medicaid eligibility for a nonimmigrant alien and the conflict between state and federal regulations; it does not involve family law, child custody, or standards for modifying custody orders. Nothing in the opinion addresses a court’s authority or criteria to modify an existing custody order to protect the safety and well-being of minor children. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for that custody-modification proposition.
Smith v. Smith, 395 Mass. 109, 130 (1985.relevant_excerpt: “This appeal involves a challenge to a regulation of the Massachusetts Department of Public Welfare that precludes certain nonimmigrant aliens from receiving medical assistance benefits (medicaid).… We agree with the plaintiff’s contention that the State regulation does not comply with the requirements of the Federal statutory and regulatory scheme, so we reverse the allowance of the Department’s motion for summary judgment.… Because we conclude that 106 Code Mass. Regs. § 503.200 does not comply with the Federal regulations, we need not decide whether it violates the Federal or State Constitutions.”

Brown v. Brown, 370 Mass. 166, 184 (1976.proposition: 7. In light of the above, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court modify the existing custody Order to ensure the safety and well-being of the minor children.
Brown v. Brown, 370 Mass. 166, 184 (1976.case_name: Director of the Division of Employee Relations v. Labor Relations Commission
Brown v. Brown, 370 Mass. 166, 184 (1976.support_reasoning: This opinion is a labor relations case about the authority of the Labor Relations Commission under Mass. G.L. c. 150E to order arbitration in connection with an illegal withholding of services. It does not concern family law, child custody, or standards for modifying a custody order to protect minor children. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for a request to modify a custody order for the safety and well-being of children.
Brown v. Brown, 370 Mass. 166, 184 (1976.relevant_excerpt: We agree that it was not authorized by the statutory provision on which the Commission relied, § 9A of new c. 150E of the General Laws (“Labor Relations: Public Employees,” effective July 1, 1974). The facts appear in the stipulation of agreed facts on which the judge below acted. On March 15, 1974, the Department of Public Welfare entered into a collective bargaining agreement with Local 509, Service Employees International Union, AFL-CIO (Union), which represented the social workers employed to carry out the department’s welfare program.

Green v. Green, 345 Mass. 211, 230 (1962.proposition: 7. In light of the above, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court modify the existing custody Order to ensure the safety and well-being of the minor children.
Green v. Green, 345 Mass. 211, 230 (1962.case_name: Boston Safe Deposit & Trust Co. v. Becker
Green v. Green, 345 Mass. 211, 230 (1962.support_reasoning: The opinion in Green v. Green deals exclusively with construction of a will, a compromise agreement, and the vesting and transfer of remainder interests in trusts, including in bankruptcy. It does not address child custody, modification of custody orders, or standards related to the safety and well-being of minor children. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for a request to modify a custody order.
Green v. Green, 345 Mass. 211, 230 (1962.relevant_excerpt: “The present controversy is between Capitol and Paul G. Becker, administrator d.b.n. of James’s estate… Capitol contends that James took by the compromise agreement an assignable remainder interest in one half the trust fund of Ann’s trust, and in the balance remaining in Antoinette’s trust, which passed to James’s trustees in bankruptcy and by assignment to Spiel and then to Capitol.”

Clark v. Clark, 320 Mass. 277, 293 (1955.proposition: 7. In light of the above, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court modify the existing custody Order to ensure the safety and well-being of the minor children.
Clark v. Clark, 320 Mass. 277, 293 (1955.case_name: Assessors of Lawrence v. Arlington Mills
Clark v. Clark, 320 Mass. 277, 293 (1955.support_reasoning: The opinion in Clark v. Clark is a Massachusetts tax abatement and Appellate Tax Board review case; it does not involve family law, custody, or modification of custody orders to protect minor children. Nothing in the holding or reasoning concerns standards for modifying custody to ensure children’s safety or well-being. The citation is therefore inapposite to the stated custody-related proposition.
Clark v. Clark, 320 Mass. 277, 293 (1955.relevant_excerpt: These seven cases originated in petitions to the assessors for abatement of taxes on real estate. The assessors refused to make any abatement, and the taxpayer appealed to the Appellate Tax Board... The board granted an abatement, and the assessors appealed to this court.

Robinson v. Robinson, 300 Mass. 520, 539.proposition: 7. In light of the above, Plaintiff respectfully requests this Honorable Court modify the existing custody Order to ensure the safety and well-being of the minor children.
Robinson v. Robinson, 300 Mass. 520, 539.support_reasoning: The case is a contract/warranty action concerning breach of warranty of fitness of food and the requirement of notice of breach under G.L. c. 106, § 38. It does not address custody, family law, or standards for modifying a custody order to protect children’s safety and well-being. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that the court should modify an existing custody order for the children’s safety.
Robinson v. Robinson, 300 Mass. 520, 539.relevant_excerpt: "This is an action of contract for breach of warranty of fitness of food sold by the defendant to the plaintiff. ... Even though the jury could have so found, the defendant would not be liable for a breach of warranty of fitness of the food sold, unless the plaintiff gave it notice of the breach within a reasonable time after he knew or ought to have known of it. G. L. (Ter. Ed.) c. 106, § 38."
